ground_truth: A faint light illuminates the screen, flickeringly revealing an eighteenth-century balustrade and a flight of stone stairs. We are looking down into the wall of the staircase from the point of view of the landing, where a branched candlestick held by Salieri's Valet ascends the stairs, accompanied by Salieri's Cook bearing a large dish of sugared cakes and biscuits. Both men are desperately worried: the Valet is thin and middle-aged; the Cook, plump and Italian, wearing shawls over their night-dresses and clogs on their feet, wheezing as they climb. The candles cast shadows on the peeling walls of the evidently old and decaying house. As they reach the salon door, a cat scuttles between their bare legs. The Valet tries the handle, and in horror, the two men stare at it as the door flies open, revealing Old Salieri lying on the floor in a pool of blood, an open razor in his hand. He has cut his throat but is still alive and gestures at them. They run to him, and we glimpse the room—an old chair, old tables piled with books, a forte-piano, a chamber-pot on the floor—as the Valet and the Cook struggle to lift their old Master and bind his bleeding throat with a napkin. The scene shifts to twenty-five dancing couples, fifty guests, ten servants, and a full orchestra at a Masquerade Ball, where music slows and reveals a crowded room of dancers executing the slow portion of a fashionable dance from the early 1820s. As the fast music returns, Old Salieri is carried out of his house on a stretcher by two attendants and placed in a horse-drawn wagon under the supervision of a middle-aged doctor in a tall hat. The driver whips up the horse, and the wagon dashes off through the still-falling snow, galloping through the snowy streets of the city. Inside, Old Salieri, wrapped in blankets and half-conscious, is held by the hospital attendants, with Doctor Gulden staring at him grimly. The wagon arrives outside the General Hospital of Vienna, and a wide, white-washed corridor is seen where Doctor Gulden walks down with Father Vogler, the hospital's Chaplain. Several patients, some visibly disturbed, wearing white linen smocks, are noted in the corridor as Doctor Gulden, in a dark frock-coat, and Vogler, in a cassock, walk. Salieri propels his wheelchair to the forte-piano and plays an unrecognizable melody, then another tune, and continues to play with growing enthusiasm.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: A dim glow lights the display, unsteadily showing an eighteenth-century railing and a set of stone steps. We are observing down into the barrier of the staircase from the perspective of the landing, where a branching candelabrum held by Salieri's Servant climbs the steps, accompanied by Salieri's Chef carrying a large platter of sweetened pastries and cookies. Both men are extremely anxious: the Servant is lean and middle-aged; the Chef, stout and Italian, wearing shawls over their sleeping-garments and clogs on their feet, wheezing as they ascend. The candles project silhouettes on the flaking walls of the evidently ancient and deteriorating abode. As they approach the salon door, a feline darts between their exposed legs. The Servant attempts the handle, and in dread, the two men gaze at it as the door swings open, showing Old Salieri lying on the ground in a pool of blood, an open razor in his hand. He has sliced his throat but is still alive and signals at them. They hurry to him, and we glimpse the chamber—an old chair, old tables stacked with tomes, a forte-piano, a chamber-pot on the floor—as the Servant and the Chef struggle to lift their old Master and bind his bleeding throat with a napkin. The scene shifts to twenty-five waltzing pairs, fifty visitors, ten attendants, and a full band at a Masquerade Gala, where music slows and shows a crowded hall of dancers performing the slow section of a trendy dance from the early 1820s. As the fast music resumes, Old Salieri is borne out of his residence on a stretcher by two aides and placed in a horse-drawn carriage under the supervision of a middle-aged physician in a tall hat. The driver urges the horse, and the carriage speeds off through the still-falling snow, racing through the snowy avenues of the metropolis. Inside, Old Salieri, enveloped in blankets and semi-conscious, is held by the hospital aides, with Doctor Gulden watching him sternly. The carriage arrives outside the General Hospital of Vienna, and a wide, white-washed corridor is seen where Doctor Gulden walks down with Father Vogler, the hospital's Chaplain. Several patients, some visibly agitated, wearing white linen smocks, are noted in the corridor as Doctor Gulden, in a dark frock-coat, and Vogler, in a cassock, walk. Salieri propels his wheelchair to the forte-piano and plays an indistinct harmony, then another tune, and continues to play with increasing zeal.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: A faint light is cast on the screen, flickeringly revealing an eighteenth-century balustrade and a flight of stone stairs. The wall of the staircase is looked down into by us from the point of view of the landing, where a branched candlestick is carried up the stairs by Salieri's Valet, accompanied by Salieri's Cook, who carries a large dish of sugared cakes and biscuits. Desperately worried are both men: the Valet is thin and middle-aged; the Cook, plump and Italian, wears shawls over their night-dresses and clogs on their feet, wheezing as they climb. Shadows are cast by the candles on the peeling walls of the evidently old and decaying house. As the salon door is reached by them, a cat scuttles between their bare legs. The handle is tried by the Valet, and in horror, the two men watch it as the door flies open, revealing Old Salieri lying on the floor in a pool of blood, with an open razor in his hand. His throat has been cut by him, but he is still alive and gestures at them. They run to him, and the room is glimpsed by us—an old chair, old tables piled with books, a forte-piano, a chamber-pot on the floor—as the Valet and the Cook lift their old Master and bind his bleeding throat with a napkin. The scene shifts to twenty-five dancing couples, fifty guests, ten servants, and a full orchestra at a Masquerade Ball, where music slows and reveals a crowded room of dancers executing the slow portion of a fashionable dance from the early 1820s. As the fast music returns, Old Salieri is carried out of his house on a stretcher by two attendants and placed in a horse-drawn wagon under the supervision of a middle-aged doctor in a tall hat. The driver whips up the horse, and the horse dashes off through the still-falling snow, galloping through the snowy streets of the city. Inside, Old Salieri, wrapped in blankets and half-conscious, is held by the hospital attendants, while Doctor Gulden stares at him grimly. The wagon arrives outside the General Hospital of Vienna, and a wide, white-washed corridor is seen, where Doctor Gulden walks with Father Vogler, the hospital's Chaplain. Several patients, some visibly disturbed, wear white linen smocks, and Doctor Gulden, in a dark frock-coat, and Vogler, in a cassock, walk by them. The forte-piano is approached by Salieri in his wheelchair, and an unrecognizable melody is played by him, then another tune by him, and he continues to play with growing enthusiasm.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: A faint light flickers, revealing an eighteenth-century balustrade and stone stairs. From the landing, Salieri's Valet, holding a candlestick, and the Cook, with a dish of sugared cakes, ascend the stairs, both worried. The Valet is thin and middle-aged; the Cook, plump and Italian, both in night-dresses and clogs, wheeze as they climb. Shadows dance on the peeling walls of the decaying house. At the salon door, a cat scuttles by, and the Valet opens the door to find Old Salieri on the floor, bleeding from a self-inflicted throat wound but still alive. They rush to help him, revealing a room with old furniture and a forte-piano. The scene shifts to a Masquerade Ball with twenty-five couples, fifty guests, ten servants, and an orchestra. As music slows, Old Salieri is carried out on a stretcher to a horse-drawn wagon, overseen by a doctor. The wagon speeds through snowy streets to Vienna's General Hospital. Inside, Doctor Gulden and Father Vogler walk a white-washed corridor with patients in white smocks. Salieri, in a wheelchair, plays an unrecognizable melody on the forte-piano, growing more enthusiastic.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: A faint light flickers, revealing an eighteenth-century balustrade and stone stairs. From the landing, Salieri's Valet with a candlestick and the Cook with sugared cakes ascend, worried. The Valet is thin and middle-aged; the plump Italian Cook wears shawls and clogs, wheezing as they climb. Shadows fall on the decaying house walls. At the salon door, a cat scuttles by. The Valet opens the door, revealing Old Salieri on the floor, bleeding with a razor in hand. They rush to him, glimpsing a room with old furniture and a forte-piano, and bind his throat with a napkin. The scene shifts to a Masquerade Ball with fifty guests, ten servants, and an orchestra. As music slows, Salieri is carried out on a stretcher to a horse-drawn wagon, overseen by a doctor in a tall hat. The wagon speeds through snowy streets. Inside, Salieri, half-conscious, is held by attendants, with Doctor Gulden watching. The wagon reaches Vienna's General Hospital. Doctor Gulden and Father Vogler walk a white-washed corridor with patients in white smocks. Salieri, in a wheelchair, plays an unrecognizable melody on the forte-piano with growing enthusiasm.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: A faint, flickering light gently illuminates the screen, gradually revealing the intricate details of an eighteenth-century balustrade and a flight of worn stone stairs. Our perspective is from the landing, looking down into the wall of the staircase, where we see Salieri's Valet ascending the stairs. He is holding a branched candlestick, its light casting a warm glow, and is accompanied by Salieri's Cook, who is carefully carrying a large dish filled with an assortment of sugared cakes and biscuits. Both men appear to be desperately worried and anxious: the Valet is a thin, middle-aged man, while the Cook is plump and of Italian descent. They are both dressed in shawls draped over their night-dresses, with clogs on their feet, wheezing as they laboriously climb the stairs. The flickering candles cast eerie shadows on the peeling walls of the evidently old and decaying house, adding to the somber atmosphere. As they finally reach the salon door, a cat suddenly scuttles between their bare legs, startling them. The Valet tentatively tries the handle, and in horror, both men stare as the door flies open, revealing Old Salieri lying on the floor in a pool of his own blood, an open razor clutched in his hand. He has attempted to cut his throat but is still alive, gesturing weakly at them. They rush to his side, and we catch a glimpse of the room—a scene of disarray with an old chair, tables piled high with books, a forte-piano, and a chamber-pot on the floor—as the Valet and the Cook struggle to lift their old Master and bind his bleeding throat with a napkin. The scene then shifts dramatically to a lively Masquerade Ball, where twenty-five dancing couples, fifty guests, ten servants, and a full orchestra are present. The music slows, revealing a crowded room of dancers gracefully executing the slow portion of a fashionable dance from the early 1820s. As the fast-paced music resumes, Old Salieri is carried out of his house on a stretcher by two attendants and placed in a horse-drawn wagon under the watchful supervision of a middle-aged doctor wearing a tall hat. The driver urges the horse forward with a whip, and the wagon dashes off through the still-falling snow, galloping swiftly through the snowy streets of the city. Inside the wagon, Old Salieri, wrapped in blankets and only half-conscious, is held securely by the hospital attendants, while Doctor Gulden stares at him with a grim expression. The wagon arrives outside the General Hospital of Vienna, where we see a wide, white-washed corridor. Doctor Gulden walks down this corridor alongside Father Vogler, the hospital's Chaplain. Several patients, some visibly disturbed and wearing white linen smocks, are noted in the corridor as Doctor Gulden, dressed in a dark frock-coat, and Vogler, in a cassock, walk by. Salieri, now in a wheelchair, propels himself to the forte-piano and begins to play an unrecognizable melody, then another tune, continuing to play with growing enthusiasm and fervor.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: A faint, flickering light gently finds its way onto the screen, gradually beginning to illuminate and reveal the intricate, ornate details of an eighteenth-century balustrade along with a flight of worn, weathered stone stairs. Our viewpoint, situated on the landing, allows us to look downward into the wall of this winding staircase, where we observe Salieri's Valet making his careful ascent up the stairs. In his hand, he holds a branched candlestick, its soft light casting a warm glow, and by his side walks Salieri's Cook, who is attentively carrying a large dish filled to the brim with an enticing assortment of sugared cakes and biscuits. Both men seem to be desperately worried and visibly anxious: the Valet is a thin, middle-aged gentleman, whereas the Cook is of Italian descent and noticeably plump. They are both clad in shawls that are draped over their night-dresses, with clogs on their feet, wheezing as they laboriously climb the winding staircase. The flickering candlelight casts eerie, unsettling shadows on the peeling walls of the evidently old and decaying house, contributing significantly to the somber and melancholic atmosphere. As they finally reach the salon door, a cat suddenly scuttles quickly between their bare legs, startling them. The Valet tentatively reaches for and tries the handle, and in a moment of horror, both men stare in shock as the door swings open, revealing Old Salieri lying on the floor, surrounded by a pool of his own blood, with an open razor clutched in his hand. He has attempted to cut his throat, yet he is still alive, weakly gesturing to them for assistance. They rush to his side, and we catch a fleeting glimpse of the room—a scene of disarray characterized by an old chair, tables piled high with books, a forte-piano, and a chamber-pot on the floor—while the Valet and the Cook frantically struggle to lift their old Master and bind his bleeding throat with a napkin. The scene then shifts dramatically to a lively, extravagant Masquerade Ball, where twenty-five dancing couples, a total of fifty guests, ten attentive servants, and a full orchestra are all present. The music gradually slows, revealing a room crowded with dancers gracefully executing the slow portion of a fashionable early 1820s dance. As the fast-paced music resumes, Old Salieri is carried out of his house on a stretcher by two attendants and is placed in a horse-drawn wagon under the vigilant supervision of a middle-aged doctor wearing a tall, distinguished hat. The driver urges the horse forward with a swift motion of his whip, and the wagon dashes off through the still-falling snow, galloping swiftly across the snowy city streets. Inside the wagon, Old Salieri, wrapped securely in blankets and only half-conscious, is held firmly by the hospital attendants, while Doctor Gulden watches him with a stern, grim expression. The wagon eventually arrives outside the General Hospital of Vienna, where we are shown a broad, white-washed corridor. Doctor Gulden walks down this corridor alongside Father Vogler, who serves as the hospital's Chaplain. Several patients, some visibly disturbed and clad in white linen smocks, are observed in the corridor as Doctor Gulden, dressed in a dark frock-coat, and Vogler, wearing a cassock, walk by. Salieri, now seated in a wheelchair, propels himself to the forte-piano and begins to play an unrecognizable melody, then another tune, continuing to play with growing enthusiasm and fervor.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: A faint light begins to illuminate the screen, flickering intermittently to reveal an eighteenth-century balustrade and a flight of stone stairs. Our perspective is from the landing, looking down into the wall of the staircase, where Salieri's Valet, holding a branched candlestick, slowly ascends the stairs. He is accompanied by Salieri's Cook, who carefully balances a large dish filled with sugared cakes and biscuits. Both men are visibly anxious, their expressions marked by desperation. The Valet, thin and middle-aged, and the Cook, plump and Italian, are dressed in shawls over their night-dresses, with clogs on their feet, and they wheeze audibly as they laboriously climb the stairs. The flickering candles cast dancing shadows on the peeling walls of the old and decaying house, adding to the eerie atmosphere. As they finally reach the salon door, a cat suddenly scuttles between their bare legs, causing a brief moment of surprise. The Valet reaches out to try the handle, and both men stare in horror as the door unexpectedly flies open, revealing Old Salieri lying on the floor in a pool of blood, an open razor clutched in his hand. Despite having cut his throat, he is still alive and gestures weakly at them. The Valet and the Cook rush to his side, and as they do, we catch a glimpse of the room—a scene filled with an old chair, old tables piled with books, a forte-piano, and a chamber-pot on the floor. The two men struggle to lift their old Master and hastily bind his bleeding throat with a napkin. The scene then shifts dramatically to a Masquerade Ball, where twenty-five dancing couples, fifty guests, ten servants, and a full orchestra are present. The music slows, revealing a crowded room of dancers executing the slow portion of a fashionable dance from the early 1820s. As the music picks up pace again, Old Salieri is seen being carried out of his house on a stretcher by two attendants. He is placed in a horse-drawn wagon under the watchful eye of a middle-aged doctor wearing a tall hat. The driver snaps the whip, urging the horse forward, and the wagon dashes off through the still-falling snow, galloping swiftly through the snowy streets of the city. Inside the wagon, Old Salieri, wrapped in blankets and only half-conscious, is held securely by the hospital attendants, while Doctor Gulden stares at him with a grim expression. The wagon eventually arrives outside the General Hospital of Vienna, where a wide, white-washed corridor comes into view. Doctor Gulden walks down this corridor alongside Father Vogler, the hospital's Chaplain. As they proceed, several patients, some visibly disturbed and wearing white linen smocks, are noted in the corridor. Doctor Gulden, dressed in a dark frock-coat, and Vogler, in a cassock, continue their walk. Meanwhile, Salieri, now in a wheelchair, propels himself to the forte-piano and begins to play an unrecognizable melody. He then transitions to another tune, continuing to play with growing enthusiasm, as if lost in the music.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: A faint light flickers over an eighteenth-century balustrade and stone stairs, revealing Salieri's Valet and Cook ascending with urgency. The Valet, thin and middle-aged, and the plump Italian Cook, both in night-dresses and clogs, carry a candlestick and a dish of sugared cakes, casting shadows on the decaying walls. Reaching the salon door, a cat darts between their legs as they open it to find Old Salieri on the floor, bleeding from a self-inflicted throat wound. They rush to assist him, binding his wound with a napkin amidst a room cluttered with old furniture and books. The scene transitions to a Masquerade Ball with dancing couples, guests, servants, and an orchestra, where the music slows to reveal the dancers' graceful movements. As the tempo quickens, Old Salieri is carried out on a stretcher to a horse-drawn wagon, overseen by a doctor in a tall hat. The wagon speeds through snowy streets, with Salieri, wrapped in blankets and semi-conscious, attended by hospital staff and observed by Doctor Gulden. Arriving at Vienna's General Hospital, Doctor Gulden and Father Vogler, the Chaplain, walk through a corridor lined with patients in white smocks. Salieri, now in a wheelchair, moves to a forte-piano and plays an unrecognizable melody, continuing with increasing enthusiasm.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: A faint light illuminates the screen, flickeringly revealing an eighteenth-century balustrade, a decorative railing often found in grand European architecture of the time, and a flight of stone stairs. We are looking down into the wall of the staircase from the point of view of the landing, where a branched candlestick held by Salieri's Valet ascends the stairs, accompanied by Salieri's Cook bearing a large dish of sugared cakes and biscuits, a common delicacy enjoyed by the European elite in the 18th century. Both men are desperately worried: the Valet is thin and middle-aged; the Cook, plump and Italian, a nationality renowned for culinary excellence, wearing shawls over their night-dresses and clogs on their feet, wheezing as they climb. The candles cast shadows on the peeling walls of the evidently old and decaying house, reminiscent of many aristocratic residences fallen into disrepair during economic hardships. As they reach the salon door, a cat, often kept in households to control vermin, scuttles between their bare legs. The Valet tries the handle, and in horror, the two men stare at it as the door flies open, revealing Old Salieri lying on the floor in a pool of blood, an open razor in his hand. He has cut his throat but is still alive and gestures at them. They run to him, and we glimpse the room—an old chair, old tables piled with books, a forte-piano, an instrument central to classical music compositions of the era, a chamber-pot on the floor—as the Valet and the Cook struggle to lift their old Master and bind his bleeding throat with a napkin. The scene shifts to twenty-five dancing couples, fifty guests, ten servants, and a full orchestra at a Masquerade Ball, a popular social gathering in the early 19th century, where music slows and reveals a crowded room of dancers executing the slow portion of a fashionable dance from the early 1820s, such as the waltz or quadrille. As the fast music returns, Old Salieri is carried out of his house on a stretcher by two attendants and placed in a horse-drawn wagon, the primary mode of ambulance transport before motor vehicles, under the supervision of a middle-aged doctor in a tall hat, a common accessory signifying status in this period. The driver whips up the horse, and the wagon dashes off through the still-falling snow, galloping through the snowy streets of the city that resemble 19th-century Vienna, a center of music and culture. Inside, Old Salieri, wrapped in blankets, a precaution against the harsh winter cold, and half-conscious, is held by the hospital attendants, with Doctor Gulden staring at him grimly. The wagon arrives outside the General Hospital of Vienna, one of the oldest and largest hospitals in Europe, and a wide, white-washed corridor is seen where Doctor Gulden walks down with Father Vogler, the hospital's Chaplain and spiritual advisor for the patients. Several patients, some visibly disturbed, wearing white linen smocks, reminiscent of the typical hospital attire of the time, are noted in the corridor as Doctor Gulden, in a dark frock-coat, and Vogler, in a cassock, walk. Salieri propels his wheelchair to the forte-piano and plays an unrecognizable melody, then another tune, and continues to play with growing enthusiasm, perhaps in an attempt to reconnect with the music that defined much of his life.

Inside Old Salieri wrapped in blankets and halfconscious is held by the hospital attendants with Doctor Gulden staring at him grimly. The wagon arrives outside the General Hospital of Vienna and a wide whitewashed corridor is seen where Doctor Gulden walks down with Father Vogler the hospital's Chaplain. test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: A faint light illuminates the screen flickeringly revealing an eighteenthcentury balustrade and a flight of stone stairs. We are looking down into the wall of the staircase from the point of view of the landing where a branched candlestick held by Salieri's Valet ascends the stairs accompanied by Salieri's Cook bearing a large dish of sugared cakes and biscuits. Salieri propels his wheelchair to the fortepiano and plays an unrecognizable melody then another tune and continues to play. with growing enthusiasm.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: A dim glow brightens the monitor, randomly displaying a nineteenth-century fountain and a walkway of wooden planks. We are peering up into the ceiling of the hallway from the vantage point of the corridor, where a twisted lantern gripped by Beethoven's Gardener descends the walkway, accompanied by Beethoven's Butler holding a tiny platter of salted fruits and pastries. Both women are anxiously puzzled: the Gardener is short and young; the Butler, thin and German, donning cloaks over their tunics and slippers on their hands, coughing as they descend. The lanterns project shapes on the crumbling ceiling of the apparent new and flourishing palace. As they approach the study entrance, a mouse darts around their bare arms. The Gardener tests the latch, and in shock, the two women gaze at it as the entrance bursts shut, concealing Young Beethoven kneeling on the ceiling in a pile of feathers, a closed scissors in his foot. He has scratched his chin but is still awake and signals to them. They crawl to him, and we glimpse the chamber—a new bench, new cabinets stacked with scrolls, a harpsichord, a goblet on the ceiling—as the Gardener and the Butler attempt to lower their young Mentor and unwrap his scratched chin with a blanket. The scene switches to twelve jumping chickens, thirty swans, five attendants, and an empty stage at a Carnival Parade, where silence slows and uncovers a sparse space of animals performing the silent portion of a traditional tune from the late 1830s. As the quick silence returns, Young Beethoven is dragged into his palace on a wheelbarrow by three nurses and placed in a cow-drawn sledge under the observation of a youthful nurse in a short cap. The pilot tugs at the mule, and the sledge strolls on through the ever-rising rain, swimming through the wet paths of the village. Outside, Young Beethoven, encased in sheets and partly alert, is supported by the refuge nurses, with Nurse Rein staring at him joyfully. The sledge departs inside the Big Refuge of Berlin, and a narrow, dark-paved chamber is observed where Nurse Rein strolls up with Brother Bauer, the refuge's Poet. Various visitors, a few visibly amused, wearing light green gowns, are noticed in the chamber as Nurse Rein, in a bright blouse, and Bauer, in a vest, stroll. Beethoven steers his scooter to the harpsichord and sings an indistinct symphony, then another jingle, and pauses to sing with dwindling excitement.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: A dim light reveals an old staircase where Salieri's Valet and Cook nervously ascend, carrying a candlestick and sugared cakes. They find Old Salieri in a pool of blood, having attempted suicide with a razor. Desperately, they bind his throat and reveal his cluttered room during the struggle. The scene shifts to a Masquerade Ball with fifty guests and an orchestra when Salieri is carried out on a stretcher by attendants, overseen by Doctor Gulden. The wagon speeds through snowy Vienna streets to the General Hospital. There, Doctor Gulden and Chaplain Father Vogler walk through a corridor past disturbed patients. Later, Salieri, in a wheelchair, plays a forte-piano with increasing fervor.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: with growing enthusiasm Salieri propels his wheelchair to the fortepiano and plays an unrecognizable melody then another tune and continues to play  Several patients some visibly disturbed wearing white linen smocks are noted in the corridor as Doctor Gulden in a dark frockcoat and Vogler in a cassock walk  The wagon arrives outside the General Hospital of Vienna and a wide whitewashed corridor is seen where Doctor Gulden walks down with Father Vogler the hospital's Chaplain  Inside Old Salieri wrapped in blankets and halfconscious is held by the hospital attendants with Doctor Gulden staring at him grimly  The driver whips up the horse and the wagon dashes off through the stillfalling snow galloping through the snowy streets of the city  As the fast music returns Old Salieri is carried out of his house on a stretcher by two attendants and placed in a horsedrawn wagon under the supervision of a middleaged doctor in a tall hat  The scene shifts to twentyfive dancing couples fifty guests ten servants and a full orchestra at a Masquerade Ball where music slows and reveals a crowded room of dancers executing the slow portion of a fashionable dance from the early 1820s  They run to him and we glimpse the room—an old chair old tables piled with books a fortepiano a chamberpot on the floor—as the Valet and the Cook struggle to lift their old Master and bind his bleeding throat with a napkin  He has cut his throat but is still alive and gestures at them  The Valet tries the handle and in horror the two men stare at it as the door flies open revealing Old Salieri lying on the floor in a pool of blood an open razor in his hand  As they reach the salon door a cat scuttles between their bare legs  The candles cast shadows on the peeling walls of the evidently old and decaying house  the Cook plump and Italian wearing shawls over their nightdresses and clogs on their feet wheezing as they climb  the Valet is thin and middleaged  Both men are desperately worried  We are looking down into the wall of the staircase from the point of view of the landing where a branched candlestick held by Salieri's Valet ascends the stairs accompanied by Salieri's Cook bearing a large dish of sugared cakes and biscuits  A faint light illuminates the screen flickeringly revealing an eighteenthcentury balustrade and a flight of stone stairs
